Additionally, 95% of junk mail could potentially be rejected if spammers do not retry sending. However, spammers may implement retries, reducing the effectiveness of these strategies. The delay strategy assumes good senders will retry, while spammers and virus-infected machines will not, but this might change if such systems are widely adopted.

rewritten_question_obscured: What impact did utilizing the filtering and sorting features have on the sensitivity to pricing and rating during booking in the used scenario within Condition 2b?
complete_answer: The S&F functions, when available and used (condition 2b), reduced price sensitivity compared to when they were not available (condition 1). Participants who used the filter and sort functions based their choices more on price or rating, leading to a more even distribution of choices across search result positions. Specifically, in condition 2b, price sensitivity by filter on price was 21.9%, and by sort on price was 22.5%, showing a reduction from condition 1 where they were 23.3%. Rating sensitivity remained comparatively stable.

facts: In condition 2 (where S&F functions were present), price sensitivity was signiﬁcantly lower than in condition 1 (where S&F func- tions were absent) [ﬁlter: F(2, 1489) = 8.88, p\.001; sort: F(2, 1489) = 12.38, p\ .001].
F(3, 3072) = 5.22, p\.001; sort: F(3, 3072) = 4.58, p\.001], indicating a decline in the average prices of the rooms that were booked across the four tasks.

The F-values indicate that the effect was strongest for the sort function.
Only the choice patterns of those who used the functions were more equally distributed over the 50 search result positions.
They were inclined to base their choices on key characteristics of the hotels (i.e., price and rating).
Those who pres- elected an acceptable price band were less responsive to higher prices because they saw fewer (variations) of them.
The S&F function thus ‘‘redistributes’’ the booking choices towards entries that are more at the middle of the initial search results page list.
Those who sorted and ﬁl- tered on price tended to choose hotel rooms that were cheaper, while participants who did this by hotel rating were more likely to choose hotels with a higher rating.

rewritten_question_obscured: How did households identified as 'Extremely Vulnerable' adjust their behaviors amidst the pandemic, and what was the impact on their financial resilience ratings in 2020?
complete_answer: 'Extremely Vulnerable' households reduced non-essential expenses by 80.7%, drew down savings by 66.2%, and increased borrowing by 43.6% as of October 2020. Despite these adjustments, emotional well-being worsened, indicated by financial stress. The financial resilience index score improved slightly to 55.69 by February 2021, but households remained under significant financial stress, affecting their overall well-being.

facts: As of June 2020 however, the mean financial resilience index score at the national level was 55.58; 54.53 in October 2020 and higher at 55.69 in February 2021, signalling improved financial resilience for individuals and families – although many households are currently being temporarily ‘cushioned’ by financial relief.

Furthermore, households which were identified as falling into the ‘Extremely Vulnerable’ segment have been shown to be taking steps to adjust to their situation and bridge through, with 80.7% significantly reducing non-essential expenses, 66.2% drawing down their savings and 43.6% increasing their borrowing to meet everyday expenses as of October 2020.

Emotional well-being impacts have worsened for ‘Extremely Vulnerable’ and ‘Financially Vulnerable’ households combined in February 2021 compared to four months prior based on the October 2020 Seymour Financial Resilience Index TM, as outlined below.

The Index tells the clear story that more financially vulnerable households are being more negatively impacted by the pandemic causing financial hardship compared to ‘Financially Resilient’ Canadians.

In February 2021, 57% of ‘Extremely Vulnerable’ and ‘Financially Vulnerable’ households combined (representing 11.08 million Canadians) completely agree that money worries causes them emotional stress, with another 35% agreeing that it causes them emotional stress, for a total of 94%.
This compares to 26% of ‘Financially Resilient’ households completely or somewhat agreeing that financial stress cause them emotional stress.
Similar impacts in terms of financial stress causing many Canadians to lose sleep at night, in particular for more financially vulnerable households.

The February 2021 Financial Well-Being study highlights lower mean ratings for Canadians’ in terms of their emotional or mental health, their physical well-being, and their relationships with friends and family compared to 2018, reflecting impact of the work-life changes and lock-down impacts on the personal well- being of many individuals and families.
Financial stress and financial vulnerability have been a mainstream issue for Canada for many years well-before the pandemic, evidenced through our many published reports.

Financial vulnerability and financial stress has been a mainstream issue for many Canadians for several years, as evidenced through the 2017-2021 Financial Well-Being studies and published through our many reports over the years.
The ‘black swan’ global event of the pandemic has caused further disruption and challenges for many Canadians (and indeed people around the world).

Work-life changes, unemployment and/or reduced working hours for many households, and other financial stressors and challenges, have caused financial vulnerability for many, with the pandemic impacting households unevenly and more vulnerable populations most affected.
For 'Extremely/Financially Vulnerable' households in October 2020, 50.7% 'Completely agree' and 38.0% 'Somewhat agree' that money worries cause them financial stress.

Trainers use this method to brainstorm key concepts, such as a company's vision and values, design practice activities for skill application, and summarize learning outcomes. complete_answer: The Bosch codepad communicates using various beeps to indicate different statuses. One short beep signals a button press or end of exit time in STAY Mode 1 or 2. Two short beeps indicate your code was accepted. Three short beeps mean the requested function was executed. One long beep signals the end of exit time in AWAY Mode, or a denied/aborted operation. A beep every second indicates Walk Test Mode is active or a warning before automatic arming. One short beep every minute signifies a system fault waiting to be acknowledged. rewritten_question_obscured: How do the authoring-centered and automation-centered strategies for modular content differ in the healthcare sector, especially regarding their effects on the transformation of the content supply chain from manual to automated processes?
complete_answer: The authoring-focused approach creates smaller modules and simplifies the manual authoring process, relying on human-guided assembly and resulting in linear gains that still require more personnel to scale. In contrast, the automation-focused approach transforms content into computable data using machines, enabling exponential scaling, reduced costs, and deep analytics into content effectiveness. This approach allows for fully automated content factory services, reduces manual errors, and supports personalized content through machine drafting and authoring. It also optimizes marketing mix and customer journey planning while meeting regulatory requirements and connecting with powerful existing platforms. The transformation from manual to automated processes in the content supply chain involves a shift from human-centric to machine-driven content creation, standardization, and compliance for machine readability, leading to a more efficient and scalable system.

facts: The content stewardship necessary to manage this process and resulting volumes and variety is only possible if the modular approach to content is automation focused.

This along with the management of duplications, expiring and retiring assets and the assurance of compliance and can, at this point, only be achieved with the help of a machine that can read content and the underlying elements and components of that content as data.

The remaining 80% of the work can be accomplished at half (or less) of the current cost while delivering close to a 10x output of fresh, high quality content that is delivered agile on an ongoing basis throughout the year.
It delivers deep insights and recommendations to improve content effectiveness and deliver on the promise of content personalization… at scale!
We believe that this approach will focus the work of creative agencies to 10-20% of their current scope and budget.
This drives the ability to execute against audience microsegments in a personalized manner to deliver great customer experience, while limiting the financial burden.
Modular content with a focus on automation is the key to achieving this goal.
It builds commercial capability to convert content into data and allows for rapid assembly and approval at scale.
Our industry’s approach to modular content has been focused on enabling a more efficient way to create and approve content by humans.
In contrast, automated modular content, as the name implies, is driven by data with machines and artificial intelligence as the primary user during the authoring process.

With machines at the center of the content supply chain, automation and exponential scaling of not only creating content but approving content becomes possible and is the guiding principle of what we call “automation focused approach” to modular content.

The payoff is not just the ability to exponentially scale up the content supply chain while keeping cost stable, but also improving creative development, customer journey planning, data, analytics, insight, and marketing mix optimization including sales force sizing.
It is centered around the authoring process which results in linear gains, that ultimately still require “more people” to substantially scale the 5Vs (volume, variety, velocity, veracity and value).

The view on modular content as “Lego blocks” that assemble into a final asset, never created a pathway towards full automation (powered by machines, not humans) capable of scaling content personalization exponentially.
This shift toward a focus on automation requires a fundamental change in how we approach modular content to meet regulatory requirements.

It also requires industry specific technology accelerators to connect powerful, existing platforms like DAMS, approval systems, authoring platforms, CRM, CMS and other MarTech with this automated, modular content approach.
Authoring focused approach (Traditional modular supply chain)
Automation focused approach (Machine powered content supply chain)
Creates smaller modules of content
Simplifies and accelerates the manual authoring process
Transforms unstructured content into computable data
Enables deep analytics and insights into content effectiveness at the component level, consistently across all channels

rewritten_question_obscured: What shifts occurred in the Canadian financial resilience index from early 2020 to early 2021, and how did this affect the emotional state of financially at-risk groups?
complete_answer: The financial resilience index scores increased from 49.58 in February 2020 to 55.69 in February 2021, indicating improved financial resilience at the national level. However, emotional well-being for 'Extremely Vulnerable' and 'Financially Vulnerable' households worsened, with 57% completely agreeing that money worries caused them emotional stress, and a total of 94% experiencing stress due to financial concerns. This contrasts with 26% of 'Financially Resilient' households reporting similar stress.

facts: Using the index, the baseline mean financial resilience score for Canada at the national level in February 2020, just before the major onset of the pandemic in Canada, was 49.58 on a scale of 0 to 100 - revealing that pre-pandemic Canadian households were, at the national level ‘Financially Vulnerable’ to financial hardship, stressors or shocks.

As of June 2020 however, the mean financial resilience index score at the national level was 55.58; 54.53 in October 2020 and higher at 55.69 in February 2021, signalling improved financial resilience for individuals and families – although many households are currently being temporarily ‘cushioned’ by financial relief.

Emotional well-being impacts have worsened for ‘Extremely Vulnerable’ and ‘Financially Vulnerable’ households combined in February 2021 compared to four months prior based on the October 2020 Seymour Financial Resilience Index TM, as outlined below.

In February 2021, 57% of ‘Extremely Vulnerable’ and ‘Financially Vulnerable’ households combined (representing 11.08 million Canadians) completely agree that money worries causes them emotional stress, with another 35% agreeing that it causes them emotional stress, for a total of 94%.

The Index tells the clear story that more financially vulnerable households are being more negatively impacted by the pandemic causing financial hardship compared to ‘Financially Resilient’ Canadians.

They also report that financial stress negatively impacts different dimensions of their well-being more than Canadians at the national level and ‘Financially Resilient’ households, which make up 30.5% of the population as of February 2021.
This compares to 26% of ‘Financially Resilient’ households completely or somewhat agreeing that financial stress cause them emotional stress.
Similar impacts in terms of financial stress causing many Canadians to lose sleep at night, in particular for more financially vulnerable households.

Financial vulnerability and financial stress has been a mainstream issue for many Canadians for several years, as evidenced through the 2017-2021 Financial Well-Being studies and published through our many reports over the years.
The ‘black swan’ global event of the pandemic has caused further disruption and challenges for many Canadians (and indeed people around the world).

Work-life changes, unemployment and/or reduced working hours for many households, and other financial stressors and challenges, have caused financial vulnerability for many, with the pandemic impacting households unevenly and more vulnerable populations most affected.

The February 2021 Financial Well-Being study highlights lower mean ratings for Canadians’ in terms of their emotional or mental health, their physical well-being, and their relationships with friends and family compared to 2018, reflecting impact of the work-life changes and lock-down impacts on the personal well- being of many individuals and families.
In February 2021, 57.1% of Extremely/Financially Vulnerable households completely agreed that money worries cause them emotional stress.
In October 2020, 50.7% of Extremely/Financially Vulnerable households completely agreed that money worries cause them emotional stress.

u0’s choice of the set of its followings B ⊆ V corresponds to the choice of the set A = h(B) of initial active nodes in V ′.

Another pertinent question about the bi- nary/multinomial MMF model is the quality of the variational inference procedure.

With 10 factors there are 1024 joint conﬂgurations of the factor vectors, and it is still possible to compute the exact distribution over all joint conﬂgurations of their settings given su–cient resources.

We then computed the variational approximation to the distribution over all joint conﬂgurations of the latent variables for these same users.

rewritten_question_obscured: How did the architecture of Pinterest's Related Pins system develop over time based on the visual snapshots provided?
complete_answer: The architecture of Pinterest's Related Pins system developed through several stages. Initially, candidate generation used the Pin-Board Graph. Memboost was introduced with hand-tuned weights to memorize past engagement. Subsequently, local candidates and pre-computed rankings were added. Finally, real-time personalized ranking was integrated with the addition of search-based, visually similar, and embedding neighbor candidates. Memboost and ranking began to be jointly learned to optimize engagement metrics.

facts: The Related Pins system comprises three major components summarized below.
The components were introduced to the system over time, and they have each evolved dramatically in their own right.
Figure 2 shows various snapshots of our architecture illustrating the evolution of both the overall system as well as each of the three components.
We ﬁrst narrow the candidate set—the set of pins eligible for Related Pin recommendations— from billions to roughly 1,000 pins that are likely related to the query pin.
A portion of our system memorizes past engagement on speciﬁc query and result pairs.
A machine-learned ranking model is applied to the pins, ordering them to maximize our target engagement metric of Save Propensity.
Initial candidate generation using Pin-Board Graph
Introduction of Memboost with hand-tuned weights
Addition of local candidates and pre-computed ranking
Integration of real-time personalized ranking with search-based, visually similar, and embedding neighbor candidates

Previous approaches for link prediction based on structural properties do not take weights of links into account.

rewritten_question_obscured: How is the customer segmentation process structured within the multi-level analysis method utilizing SOM for daily activity profiles?
complete_answer: The multi-level exploratory data analysis approach for customer segmentation involves five steps: 1) Analyze each application separately and cluster daily activity profiles, resulting in typical application days. 2) Form a global daily activity profile by replacing initial profiles with binary vectors. 3) Cluster these global profiles to obtain typical day profiles that summarize application usage. 4) Attribute each customer's daily profile to a typical day cluster and characterize the customer by the proportion of days spent in each cluster. 5) Cluster the customers based on these activity profiles to identify typical customers, ultimately linking customer behavior to application usage patterns.

facts: Our approach is organized in ﬁve steps (see Figure 6):
In a ﬁrst step, we analyze each application separately.
We cluster the set of all the daily activity proﬁles (irrespective of the customers) by application.

In a second step we gather the results of previous segmentations to forma global daily activity proﬁle: for one given day, the initial traﬃc proﬁle for an application is replaced by a vector with as many dimensions as segments of typical days obtained previously for this application.
The binary proﬁles are then concatenated to form the global daily activity proﬁle (the applications are correlated at this level for the day).
We have developed a multi-level exploratory data analysis approach based on SOM.
We obtained a map with a limited number of clusters (Figure 4): the typical days for the application.

As a result we end up, for each application, with a set of “typical ap- plication days” proﬁles which allow us to understand how the customers are globally using their broadband access along the day, for this application.
The proﬁle is attributed to its cluster; all the components are worth zero except the one associated with the represented segment (Figure 5).
This com- ponent is set to one.
In a third step, we cluster the set of all these daily activity proﬁles (ir- respective of the customers).

Each daily proﬁle of a customer is attributed to its “typ- ical day” cluster and we characterize this customer by a proﬁle which gives the proportion of days spent in each “typical day” for the month.
In a ﬁfth step, we cluster the customers as described by the above activ- ity proﬁles and end up with “typical customers”.
The ﬁrst step leads to the formation of 9 to 13 clusters of “typical ap- plication days” proﬁles, depending on application.
As a result we end up with a limited number of “typical day” proﬁles which summarize the daily activity proﬁles.
In a fourth step, we turn to individual customers described by their own set of daily proﬁles.
This last clustering allows to link customer to daily activity on applications.
The process (Figure 6) exploits the hierarchical structure of the data: a customer is deﬁned by his days and a day is deﬁned by its hourly traﬃc volume on the applications.

This means every delegation link must have a corresponding vote-visibility link in the opposite direction to comply with the minimal transparency requirement.

facts: Treating the set of delegations and votes as a graph, we observe the minimal transparency-compliant vote-visibility graph is the transpose of the vote delegation graph.
Every delegation link must have a corresponding vote-visibility link in the opposite direction.
In the latter, open-head arrows indicate 'has-votes-visible-to' relations.
The vote-visibility restrictions of the Golden Rule are unidirectional.
A user could receive delegated power from another user without knowing about that user or their votes.

rewritten_question_obscured: In what way does the PLM framework address the challenges of complexity for e-mobility offerings within smart energy solutions?
complete_answer: The PLM approach for smart energy products involves a holistic product lifecycle management framework encompassing PLM strategy, PLM process, product architecture, and PLM IT architecture. It addresses complexity by enabling synchronization of product development, market management, and retirement processes, ensuring a strong link to customer needs management. For e-mobility services, distinct product development processes are required, such as those for energy tariffs versus complex innovations like e-mobility. This framework helps manage complexity and adapt product portfolios quickly in response to technological and market dynamics.

facts: If they are to master the related organizational and technical IT challenges, they will have to develop a holistic product lifecycle management approach which will enable them to adapt their product portfolios quickly.

The framework encompasses the four dimensions of PLM strategy, PLM process, product architecture, and PLM IT architecture and should be used from energy providers as an orientation for their processes and products in the future (cf.

For example the development of an energy tariff, as incremental innovation, requires completely another product development process design as the introduction of new innovation complex products and services in the context of e-mobility (cf. Golovatchev, J.; Budde, O. et al, 2010b)

The purpose of the domain ‘PLM strategy’ is the alignment of the innovation and marketing strategy with the overall PLM strategy to allow for a synchronization of the product development, market management and retirement processes.

In order to do so, a strong link to customer needs management has to be ensured, as well as the safeguarding of lifecycle-oriented product and project portfolio management – controlling and monitoring the innovation and product pipelines.
In particular, for the utiltiy companies the design of PLM process variants and agile process play very important role by the development of various innovations.
A strategic PLM process management defines the cornerstones of the PLM process by introducing PLM process variants according to innovation level and by implementing consistence PLM process reporting.
Product lifecycle management (PLM) has the potential to cope with this complexity trap and to speed up innovations while reducing costs.

complete_answer: The five key resiliency scales from the Revving Up survey used to forecast academic outcomes are: importance of college, meaningful motivation to learn, classroom confidence, physical symptoms of distress, and academic stress. These scales are part of a prediction formula developed through Discriminant Analysis. The prediction formula was tested using a holdout method, showing stability across samples, with a prediction accuracy of 60.5% for failing students and 56.5% for successful students in the second sample. A cutoff score of 0.10 divides students into high (success) and low (failure) risk groups. The prediction score explains 5% of the total variance in academic status, highlighting its capacity to identify at-risk students, especially those with low scores.

facts: The combination of subscales that best predicted academic success or failure were importance of college, meaningful motivation to learn, classroom confidence, physical symptoms of distress, and academic stress.
This cutoff correctly predicted 59.9% of failing students and 59.1% of successful students.

In the second random split of the data set, the prediction formula developed with the first half correctly classifying 60.5% of failing students and 56.5% of successful students, with Chi Square significant at p<.001.
This provides strong evidence that the prediction formula is stable, and not dependent on a particular sample of students.
While all five subscales contributed to the prediction power of the equation, the subscale that was most predictive of academic success was a student’s belief in the importance of going to college.
This correctly predicted the academic status of 60% of failing students and 58% of successful students, for a total accuracy rate of 58.7%.
The prediction score explained 5% of the total variance in students’ academic status.
These five resiliency indicators included importance of college, meaningful motivation to attend school, classroom confidence, physical symptoms, and academic stress.
The results indicated that five resiliency indicators were able to differentiate successful students from unsuccessful students.
Although this is not a great deal of variance, when students obtain scores that are unusually low, those scores are highly predictive of academic failure.
A table was generated showing the probability of subsequent Academic Success and Academic Failure based on the combined Prediction Score.

While risk is not as predictive for the middle range of students, the Revving Up survey does appear able to predict the higher risk students with a good probability and could be used by school administrators to identify at-risk students.

rewritten_question_obscured: In what way are ADSL users categorized based on the clustering of their daily usage patterns into common daily profiles and customer types?
complete_answer: ADSL users are categorized by clustering their daily usage patterns into 'typical days', which include inactive days and days with varying activity levels based on specific time periods and intensities. These 'typical days' are further used to classify users into 'typical customers', focusing on the prevalence of certain 'typical days' in their behavior profiles. The clustering process identifies patterns of application usage (like web down) during different times of the day and groups users with similar profiles.

facts: As a result we end up with a limited number of “typical day” proﬁles which summarize the daily activity proﬁles.

Each daily proﬁle of a customer is attributed to its “typ- ical day” cluster and we characterize this customer by a proﬁle which gives the proportion of days spent in each “typical day” for the month.
In a ﬁfth step, we cluster the customers as described by the above activ- ity proﬁles and end up with “typical customers”.

Their behaviours can be summarized into inactive days, days with a mean or high activity on some limited time periods (early or late evening, noon for instance), and days with a very high activity on a long time segment (working hours, afternoon or night).
This last clustering allows to link customer to daily activity on applications.
The ﬁrst step leads to the formation of 9 to 13 clusters of “typical ap- plication days” proﬁles, depending on application.
Their behaviours are diﬀerent in terms of traﬃc time periods and in- tensity.
10 percent of the days show a high daily activity on the threeSOM based data mining approach to ADSL customer behaviors analysisapplications, 25 percent of the days are inactive days.
The last clustering leads to the formation of 12 clusters of customers which can be characterized by the preponderance of a limited number of typical days.
The second clustering leads to the formation of 14 clusters of “typical days”.

Figure 8 illustrates the characteristic behaviour of one “typical customer” (cluster 6) which groups 5 percent of the very active customers on all the applications (with a high activity all along the day, 7 days out of 10 and very little days with no activity).
The visual inspection of the left part of Figure 8 shows that the mean customer associated with the cluster is mainly active on “typical day 12” for 78 percent of the month.

rewritten_question_obscured: What fiscal difficulties did IGMA encounter in the 2019-2020 fiscal year because of the pandemic, and what plans were made by the Board to tackle these issues?
complete_answer: IGMA faced a financial challenge with a slightly higher deficit of $249.08 in FY 2019-2020 due to COVID-19. Plans made by the Board to tackle these issues included maintaining the same budgets for FY 2020-2021, exploring online sales of Gallery of the Guild pieces, and seeking fundraising suggestions from IGMA members.

facts: FY 2019-2020 was impacted by COVID- 19, necessitating the cancellation of many IGMA activities and the inability to increase income.
We ended the year with a slightly higher deficit ($249.08) than FY 2018-2019.

Your IGMA Board of Trustees voted to roll forward the same budgets for FY 2020-2021 as were approved for FY 2019-2020 but note that FY 2020-2021 is still an unknown regarding the types of gatherings and activities that we are used to.

In the meantime, the Board is exploring ways to generate income during this unique time, including the offering of the Gallery of the Guild pieces through online sales (see https://www.igma.org/members/gallery_of_guild.html).
If members of IGMA have suggestions of other ways to generate income or have fund raising experience, please do not hesitate to contact a member of the Board.
Fortunately, membership income increased slightly and our new Guild Administrator was able to secure a PPP loan to help with the financial burden.
If we are able to return to our gatherings and activities in 2020-2021, we will have the ability to increase income through our auctions and in-person Gallery of the Guild sales.

rewritten_question_obscured: How did finance app interaction change in the UK during the summer of 2016 around the time of the Brexit vote?
complete_answer: There is a noticeable peak in finance app engagement on June 24th, the day the referendum result was announced, followed by a heightened level of engagement for four weeks, eventually returning to pre-announcement levels by the end of July. Usage was stable during weekdays with drops on weekends throughout the summer.

facts: We observe a pattern of stable usage during the week and a drop during the weekend as well as a peak on June 24th, the day the referendum result was announced.
We further observe a long-term effect in the usage of ﬁnance apps during the four weeks after the referendum announce- ment compared to the weeks before.
The usage comes back to a similar volume as before the announcement at the end of July.
In addition to the short-term impact of the Brexit referendum out- come on news and ﬁnance apps, we are also interested in the long- term impact on user behavior.
In particular, we are interested in the longevity of the increase in engagement with the ﬁnance apps, which were most impacted after the day of the referendum.

rewritten_question_obscured: Can you describe the multi-step method involving SOM for clustering customer daily activity profiles and explain the role of 'typical application days' in this method?
complete_answer: The approach consists of a five-step process utilizing Self-Organizing Maps (SOM) for clustering customer daily activity profiles. Initially, daily activity profiles are clustered by application to create 'typical application days,' which summarize behaviors such as inactivity, mean or high activity during specific periods, and very high activity over long periods. These typical days form the basis for further analysis. They are used to form global daily activity profiles by replacing the initial traffic profile with vectors representing typical day segments. Further clustering yields 'typical day' profiles summarizing daily activity across applications. Customers are characterized by the proportion of days spent in each 'typical day' cluster over a month, leading to the identification of 'typical customers.' The image illustrates the clustering of daily volumes for a web down application, showing typical activity patterns.

facts: We have developed a multi-level exploratory data analysis approach based on SOM.
Our approach is organized in ﬁve steps (see Figure 6):
We cluster the set of all the daily activity proﬁles (irrespective of the customers) by application.
We obtained a map with a limited number of clusters (Figure 4): the typical days for the application.

In a second step we gather the results of previous segmentations to forma global daily activity proﬁle: for one given day, the initial traﬃc proﬁle for an application is replaced by a vector with as many dimensions as segments of typical days obtained previously for this application.
In a ﬁrst step, we analyze each application separately.

As a result we end up, for each application, with a set of “typical ap- plication days” proﬁles which allow us to understand how the customers are globally using their broadband access along the day, for this application.
Such “typical application days” form the basis of all subsequent analysis and inter- pretations.
The proﬁle is attributed to its cluster; all the components are worth zero except the one associated with the represented segment (Figure 5).
This com- ponent is set to one.
The binary proﬁles are then concatenated to form the global daily activity proﬁle (the applications are correlated at this level for the day).
As a result we end up with a limited number of “typical day” proﬁles which summarize the daily activity proﬁles.

Each daily proﬁle of a customer is attributed to its “typ- ical day” cluster and we characterize this customer by a proﬁle which gives the proportion of days spent in each “typical day” for the month.
In a ﬁfth step, we cluster the customers as described by the above activ- ity proﬁles and end up with “typical customers”.
All the segmentations are performed with dedicated SOMs (experiments have been done with the SOM Toolbox package for matlab (Vesanto et al. (2000)).
The ﬁrst step leads to the formation of 9 to 13 clusters of “typical ap- plication days” proﬁles, depending on application.
In a third step, we cluster the set of all these daily activity proﬁles (ir- respective of the customers).
This last clustering allows to link customer to daily activity on applications.
The process (Figure 6) exploits the hierarchical structure of the data: a customer is deﬁned by his days and a day is deﬁned by its hourly traﬃc volume on the applications.

rewritten_question_obscured: In version 9.0.1 of MaxCS, what are the newly introduced aspects concerning password rules and managing overloaded trunk lines?
complete_answer: In version 9.0.1 of MaxCS, password rules now include restrictions such as disallowing default passwords, passwords containing the extension number, and simple patterns like sequences or identical digits. Users must change expired passwords set by MaxAdministrator upon login. For managing overloaded trunk lines, the Busy Trunk Queuing feature allows calls to be queued and distributed to multiple call centers, using virtual extensions to route calls when channels become available.

facts: Default Password – Disallow password entry if the password is the system default password.

Extension Number Inside – Disallow password entry if the password contains the extension number
Expired Password Not Allowed–When enabled, if a password is expired, users are prompted to change the pass- word when they login.
In this release, MaxCS can be configured to queue and distribute the calls to multiple call centers.

When a virtual extension is called and there are no available trunk channels to the target call center, the call gets put into a trunk busy queue (specific to each virtual extension) until a trunk channel frees up.
Some password security related settings currently available in ExtChecker tool are added to this release.
Simple Pattern –Disallow password entry if the digits are all the same or if it is a sequence of sequential digits.

User must change password set by MaxAdmin – After setting an extension’s password from MaxAdministrator, the password will be marked as expired, and the user will have to set a new password when logging in.
A virtual exten- sion can be configured to route the call to a target call center.
The incoming trunk calls can be routed using DNIS Routing, Auto Attendant or some other means available in MaxCS.
One SIP Group can be configured to route calls to each target call center with the desired number of SIP trunk channels.
Calls will be distributed to the target call center in the order that they come in.

rewritten_question_obscured: According to the Minister's Annual Plan, what actions will the Manitoba government implement to improve accessibility after the pandemic?
complete_answer: The Manitoba government plans to enhance accessibility post-COVID by maintaining its commitment to The Accessibility for Manitobans Act, ensuring access to goods and services, and promoting accessible employment. The Manitoba Accessibility Fund will offer grants to support accessibility initiatives, such as raising awareness, preventing and removing barriers, developing accessibility standards, and creating public awareness campaigns. Additionally, the government will continue providing foundational tools, training, and guidelines for grant applications with stakeholder consultations for maximum impact.

facts: Going forward, the government’s commitment remains to its citizens in transitioning to a post-COVID Manitoba and ensuring that accessibility remains at the forefront of these plans.

I am particularly pleased to use this opportunity to announce the Manitoba Accessibility Fund, which will provide grants to businesses, non-profit organizations, municipalities and others to help make Manitoba accessible for everyone.

As described in this plan, the government will continue to provide foundational tools and training to support each of the accessibility standards (regulations), and to build public awareness about an #AccessibleMB.

As Minister of Families and Minister responsible for Accessibility, I am pleased to share the government’s plans to implement The Accessibility for Manitobans Act (AMA) during the fiscal years April 1 to March 31, 2021/22 and 2022/23.
The Manitoba government remains committed to achieving this outcome, especially as we emerge from a global pandemic.

Since the onset of the pandemic in March 2020, the barriers to daily activities caused by COVID-19 have created a broader understanding about the importance of facilitating access to goods and services and assuring accessible employment.
This office supporting the Minister responsible for Accessibility and the Accessibility Advisory Council, and is charged with the implementation of The Accessibility for Manitobans Act.
The Manitoba government has established the Accessibility Standards for Customer Service (2015) and Employment (2019).
Manitoba Accessibility Fund to support community and business initiatives beginning in 2022/23, with targeted stakeholder consultation in 2021/22 to ensure maximum impact of the new fund.
Organizations that have obligations under the AMA are eligible to apply for grants.
To achieve greater access and inclusion in Manitoba by promoting accessibility law and practices through education, awareness and collaboration with communities, organizations and businesses.

The AMA commits government to significant progress by 2023, with the anticipated establishment of all five standards by the end of 2023, including those focused on Information and Communications, Transportation and the Design of Public Spaces.
In the future, the Manitoba Accessibility Fund will also apply to infrastructure investments that may be required by accessibility standards still under development.
These investments could include improvements in web accessibility, design of outdoor spaces, and accessible transportation.

Beginning in 2021/22, the government will develop the guidelines for the grant and seek feedback from stakeholders on how to ensure the Manitoba Accessibility Fund has the broadest possible impact in creating a more accessible province.

rewritten_question_obscured: How does TPControl facilitate managing connection profiles with AMX NetLinx systems, considering aspects like network settings, unique identifiers, and file slot assignments?
complete_answer: TPControl facilitates managing connection profiles with AMX NetLinx systems by ensuring WiFi is enabled and connected to the correct IP Network, configuring the HOST field with the correct IP address of the AMX NetLinx control system, and assigning unique Device IDs for avoiding conflicts. The 'Connect using profile' window allows selection and management of profiles, where each profile contains connection-specific information including network settings and unique identifiers. For multi-TP4 file versions, it allows defining specific TP4 File Slots for each profile. TPControl supports five user-definable profiles, which can be dynamically updated using the API to provide limitless configurations. Additionally, TPControl can assign and recall TP4 files to profiles, managing file slot assignments through an interface or the API.

facts: Ensure WiFi is enabled on the device, and that it is connected to the correct IP Network.

Determine the IP address of the AMX NetLinx control system, and ensure that the HOST field within Settings for TPControl has been configured with the IP address of the AMX NetLinx control system e.g. 'Manage Profiles → Profile x → HOST'.
Ensure that a unique, and correct Device ID has been configured within Settings for TPControl e.g. 'Manage Profiles → Profile x → Device ID'.
Within TPControl, the Connect using profile window provides a method to very quickly select or change between connection profiles.
For multi-TP4 file enabled versions of TPControl, the Connect using profile window also provides a method for defining the specific TP4 File Slot to use for each profile.

Although there are only five physical profiles provided, our API can be used to dynamically update any profile, providing limitless profile configurations, which can easily be recalled using either the Connect using profile window, or using buttons defined within the user interface design.
Furthermore, ensure the IP address assigned to the device is valid.
All devices connecting to an AMX NetLinx control system must have unique identifiers in order to connect and operate properly.
If the Device ID conflicts with another connected device, one or both devices may not connect, or may work irregularly until the conflict is resolved.
Is ICSP Encryption enabled on the AMX NetLinx control system?
If so, ensure that the connection profile is configured with the relevant ICSP Encryption credentials.
Profiles contain connection specific information that TPControl uses when communicating with an AMX NetLinx master.
Five user-definable profiles are provided in TPControl (see Manage Profiles above).
For multi-TP4 file enabled versions of TPControl, the Connect using profile window provides a method for defining the specific TP4 File Slot to use for each profile.
To accomplish the same result using our API, issue the command: “'TPCCMD-1;TP4FileSlot,3;'” Essentially that translates to “Assign TP4 File Slot 3, to Profile 1”
To select a profile, simply select the profile name.
TPControl will attempt to connect to the AMX NetLinx control system using the assigned profile connection settings, and load the applicable TP4 file design assigned to the profile.
NOTE: As standard, any licensed device includes 2 x TP4 File Slots.
However, there is no limit to the number of TP4 File Slots that can be added to the device.
NOTE: When a profile is selected that has no assigned TP4 file, the last used TP4 file will be used.

When TPControl connects to a BYOD Licensed system; ● If the BYOD TP4/UI file on the BYOD licensed NetLinx Master has changed since the last time TPControl connected (or this is the first time connecting to the system), TPControl will retrieve the BYOD TP4/UI file and assign it to FILE SLOT 0 for the current active connection profile, and then display the BYOD TP4/UI file.
● Otherwise, TPControl will display the last FILE SLOT that was assigned to the current active profile.
